titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: This morning's paper contains an appeal to the Nation to follow the King's example. It is signed by the two Archbishops,
. On the other side there is an excellent letter from
' in the name of liberty. I led

in the teeth of a furious gale to see the Choirboys' sports. Then I went to Newcastle, in order to dine with Meade–Falkner, & be shown the Elswick Works. He met me at the station, & took me to the Club where we dined. Sir Percy Girouard & M

West (the chief shell–manufacturer) also dined. We drank champagne in spite of the King's Example, & I observed that a company of soldiers were doing the same. Possibly they also await the decision of the Government. After dinner we motored to the works, & for two hours I was conducted through immense workshops – more than 1000 feet long – all crowded with machines, & working night & day in the manufacture of every variety of shell. I observed the large number of girls & women employed. The elaborate provisions for testing the shells were explained to me. I came back to Durham by the midnight train.
